author: Maarten Mittner
title: Bonds firmer as rand steadies following disappointing US jobs data | Markets
text:
Picture: BUSINESS DAY SOUTH African bonds were firmer in the late afternoon on Thursday as the rand recovered from weaker levels on the day on marginally worse than expected nonfarm payroll data from the US.
The data caused the dollar to retract against the euro, resulting in marginal rand gains.
Nonfarm payrolls rose a seasonally adjusted 223,000 in June from a revised 254,000 in May, which was initially stated as 280,000, and an expected 233,000. April’s gain was revised to 187,000 from a previously reported 221,000, indicating weaker job creation than initially thought.
The unemployment rate fell to 5.3% in June, compared to 5.5% the prior month. The rate is the lowest since April 2008.
At 3.31pm, the benchmark R186 was bid at 8.245% and offered at 8.235% from Wednesday’s close of 8.260%.
The middle-dated R207 was bid at 7.730% and offered at 7.720% from a close of 7.770% previously.
The rand was at R12.2587, from a weakest level of R12.3579 on the day and a previous close of R12.2540.
The euro was at $1.1086 from a previous close of $1.1054.
Traders said it was mainly local buying that was supporting the bond market at present.
"Local participants bought R1.3bn on Wednesday and foreign participants sold R665m of South African paper," Barclays Research said in a note.
Market participants are also keeping an eye on the latest Greece debt developments for further market direction.
